revision.text:
{{Infobox Folk tale |Folk_Tale_Name = The Three Spinners |Image_Name = Illustration at page 118 in Grimm's Household Tales (Edwardes, Bell).png |Image_Caption = 1912 illustration by [[Robert Anning Bell]] |AKA = The Seven Little Pork Rinds
And Seven! |Aarne-Thompson Grouping = 501 |Mythology = |Country = [[Germany]]
[[Italy]] |Region = |Origin_Date = |Published_In = ''[[Grimm's Fairy Tales]]''
''[[Italian Folktales]]'' }} "'''The Three Spinners'''" is a German [[fairy tale]] [[Grimm's Fairy Tales|collected]] by the [[Brothers Grimm]].Jacob and Wilheim Grimm, ''Grimm's Fairy Tales'', [http://www.surlalunefairytales.com/rumpelstiltskin/stories/3spinners.html "The Three Spinners"] It is tale no 14 and [[Aarne–Thompson]] type 501. It is widespread throughout Europe.Italo Calvino, ''Italian Folktales'' p 716 {{ISBN|0-15-645489-0}} It has obvious parallels to [[Rumpelstiltskin]] and [[Frau Holle]], and obvious differences, so that they are often compared. [[Giambattista Basile]] includes an Italian literary fairy tale, '''The Seven Little Pork Rinds''', in his 1634 work, the [[Pentamerone]]''.Jack Zipes, ''The Great Fairy Tale Tradition: From Straparola and Basile to the Brothers Grimm'', p 585, {{ISBN|0-393-97636-X}} [[Italo Calvino]]'s ''[[Italian Folktales]]'' includes a variant, ''And Seven!''.Italo Calvino, ''Italian Folktales'' p 14-18 {{ISBN|0-15-645489-0}} The first edition of ''Grimm's Fairy Tales'' contained a much shorter variant, '''Hateful Flax Spinning''', but it is "The Three Spinners" that became well-known. ==Synopsis== Once there was a beautiful-but-lazy girl who would not spin. While her mother beats her for it, the Queen, passing by, overhears and asks the reason for the punishment. Ashamed to admit that her daughter is lazy, the woman replies that the girl spins so much that her mother cannot afford to buy enough [[flax]] to keep her occupied. The Queen, impressed by such industry, offers to take the girl with her. Once at the castle, the queen takes the girl to a room filled with flax. If she spins it all within three days, she'll be rewarded with marriage to the queen's oldest son. Two days later, the queen returns and is amazed to find the flax untouched. The girl pleads that homesickness has kept her from spinning, but she realizes that excuse will not serve her twice. [[Rule of three (writing)|Three]] women appear in the room that night. One has a grotesquely swollen foot; the second, an overgrown thumb; the third, a pendulous lip. They offer to spin all the flax for the girl if she will invite them to her wedding, introduce them as her aunts, and seat them at the high table. She agrees, and they commence and complete the spinning. In the morning, the queen is satisfied to see the flax all spun. She arranges for the wedding to her son, the prince, and the girl asks to invite her "aunts". When they appear, the king asks how they came to have such deformities, and the three explain that they come from their years of spinning. The king forbids his beautiful daughter-in-law to spin again. ===Variant: Hateful Flax Spinning=== A king orders his queen and daughters to spin all the time. One day, he gives them a great box of flax to spin, to his daughters' distress. The queen invites three hideous old maids to come to the castle and spin. The king sees them and asks the cause of their deformities. Their answer: from spinning. The king forbids his wife and daughters to spin again. ==The Seven Little Pork Rinds== A girl eats seven pieces of bacon, leaving none for her mother. While the mother beats her for her [[gluttony]], a passing merchant asks the reason, and the woman replies that her daughter is ruining her health by working too hard. The merchant decides on the spot to marry this industrious girl. The now-married merchant goes on a journey, leaving his wife the spinning. Making an effort to spin, she flicks a passersby with water; some passing fairies are so amused by this that they offer to do the spinning for her. Despite their aid, the merchant's wife claims that the spinning has made her ill, and the merchant decides not to require her to spin any more, as her mother must have been right about her overworking. ===And Seven!=== In this version, as in the one just described, the part of the king is taken by a merchant; similarly, the mother berates her daughter for "seven" – meaning seven bowls of soup that the girl has eaten – but the mother pretends that they are spindles of [[hemp]] that the girl has spun. The women helpers in this version – who also are deformed from their years of spinning – instruct the girl to invite them to her wedding by calling their names. If she does not do so, they warn her, she will be worse off than she would have been had they not spun for her. She forgets the names and puts off the wedding while she tries to recall them. The merchant sees the three women cavorting in the forest and hears them call out their names, similar to the scene in [[Rumpelstiltskin]]; he describes this to his bride in hopes of amusing her and getting her to agree to a wedding date. She is therefore able to invite her helpers and bring about the happy ending as in "The Three Spinners". A Puerto Rican version exists, with three Holy Souls in [[Purgatory]] replacing the fairies, and a merchant in place of the king. The heroine in this version is an orphan abused by an aunt. ==See also== {{Portal|Children's literature}} *[[The Lazy Spinner]] *[[The Three Aunts]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{wikisource-inline}} *{{Commonscat-inline}} *[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/grimm014.html ''The Three Spinning Women'' and ''Hateful Flax Spinning''] {{Brothers Grimm}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Three Spinners}} [[Category:German fairy tales]] [[Category:Grimms' Fairy Tales]] [[Category:Flax]] [[Category:Textiles in mythology and folklore]] [[Category:Fictional trios]] [[Category:Female characters in fairy tales]]

revision.comment: {{Oregon-stub}} {{Sculpture-stub}}
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Untitled | image = Fountain (Eugene, Oregon).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = The fountain and sculpture in 2011 | artist = [[Tom Hardy (artist)|Tom Hardy]] | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1952}} | completion_date = | type = Fountain, sculpture | material = Sculpture: [[Bronze sculpture|Bronze]]
Base: Concrete, stone | subject = Fish | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | condition = "Well maintained" (1993) | city = [[Eugene, Oregon]], United States | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|44.05082|-123.09145|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = USA Oregon Eugene#USA Oregon | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Eugene, Oregon | owner = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Untitled''''' is an outdoor 1952 fountain and sculpture by [[Tom Hardy (artist)|Tom Hardy]], installed at the [[Park Blocks (Eugene, Oregon)|Park Blocks]] in Eugene, Oregon, United States. ==Description and history== [[File:Eugene Saturday Market-4.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The fountain during [[Eugene Saturday Market]]]] Tom Hardy's untitled fountain (1952) is installed at the northeast corner of Eugene's Park Blocks, near the intersection of 8th Avenue and Oak Street. The fountain's [[bronze sculpture]] depicts a school of fish, possibly salmon, jumping in and out of the water and measures approximately {{Convert|69|in|m}} x {{Convert|18|ft|m}}, {{Convert|8|in|m}} x {{Convert|5|ft|m}}.{{cite web|title=Untitled, (sculpture).|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!328726~!0#focus|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]]|accessdate=October 7, 2015}} Surrounding the sculpture are five water jets. The fountain's base is made of concrete and embedded stones, and measures approximately {{Convert|24|in|m}} x {{Convert|40|ft|m}} x {{Convert|40|ft|m}}. The work was surveyed and deemed "well maintained" by the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s "[[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]]" program in August 1993. It was administered the Cultural Services Division of the City of Eugene's Library, Recreation and Cultural Services Department at that time. ==See also== {{Portal|Oregon|Visual arts}} * [[1952 in art]] * ''[[Hatfield Fountain]]'' (1989) by Tom Hardy, [[Lawrence Halprin]], and Scott Stickney (Salem, Oregon) * [[List of public art in Eugene, Oregon]] * ''[[Running Horses]]'' (1986) by Tom Hardy (Portland, Oregon) ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1952 establishments in Oregon]] [[Category:1952 sculptures]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Oregon]] [[Category:Concrete sculptures in Oregon]] [[Category:Fish in art]] [[Category:Fountains in Oregon]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Eugene, Oregon]] [[Category:Stone sculptures in Oregon]] {{Oregon-stub}} {{Sculpture-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=May 2014}}
[[File:Altes Museum Berlin (11).JPG|thumb|Two objects from the trove]] The '''Vettersfelde Treasure''' or '''Witaszkowo Treasure''' is a treasure trove, which was found by chance in what was then Vettersfelde in the [[Province of Brandenburg]] (modern [[Witaszkowo]], near [[Gubin, Poland|Gubin]], [[Poland]]) in 1882, and is now in the [[Antikensammlung Berlin]]. The objects in the trove are connected to the animal-themed art of the [[Scythians]]. The origin of the trove remains mysterious.
Among the most significant items in the trove are: * an [[electrum]] plaque (41 x 15 cm, 608 g) in the shape of a fish,<ref>Petre Alexandrescu, « Zum goldenen Fisch von Witaszkowo, ehem. Vettersfelde », in ''L'aigle et le dauphin : études d'archéologie pontique'', Editura enciclopedică, 1999.</ref> which probably dates to the end of the 6th century BC. According to Furtwängler, it was originally an ornament (''sema'') on a shield. The body of the fish is covered by little animals in relief, including a [[Black panther|panther]] catching a [[boar]], and a [[lion]] catching a [[deer]], and the tail is made up of two rams' heads. It is believed to have been made by the artisans of an [[Ionians|Ionian]] colony on the northern coast of the [[Black Sea]], such as [[Olbia]] or [[Panticapaeum]], to cater to the tastes of a Scythian prince. * a golden plaque intended to cover the upper part of a sheath for an [[Acinaces]] (a type of dagger used by Scythians) and decorated with animals (fish, vultures, deer, boar). Length: 19 cm. 6th century BC. * a golden object made up of four disks, each decorated with animals around a central boss, and a smaller central disk. It might have been part of a breast plate or a harness. Height: 17 cm. 6th century BC. Other highlights include pendants of braided wire, a massive [[torc]]. Part of the find went to Berlin and was kept with a suit of [[Scythian]] armour, which dated from around 500 BC. Other, smaller objects from the trove were sold or melted down.
The discovery began a long scholarly debate. The presence of these objects so far into northern Europe was explained by a Scythian expedition into central Europe, with the trove forming the grave-offerings of a Scythian prince, who had made it to [[Brandenburg]]. One such expedition is attested at the end of the sixth century BC as a result of [[Darius I|Darius]]' Scythian expedition (513 BC). Newer research on the find location argues that it might have been deposited as a sacrifice after being taken as booty from a Scythian prince. The presence of Scythians in this area is otherwise only suggested by the discover of three-fluted arrowheads, but these were regularly used by other [[Eurasian nomads]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== Bibliography== * ''[[Reallexikon der Germanischen Altertumskunde]]'', sv. "Vettersfelde". Vol. 32, pp. 317–330 * Adolf Furtwängler. ''Der Goldfund von Vettersfelde.'' Berlin 1883 [http://digi.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/diglit/bwpr1883 UB Heidelberg]
[[Category:Scythian art]] [[Category:Iranian archaeological artifacts]] [[Category:Treasure troves of the Iron Age]] [[Category:Treasure troves of Germany]] [[Category:1882 in Europe]] [[Category:1882 archaeological discoveries]]

{{other uses}} {{POV|date=May 2017}} [[File:Francesco Porzio, Monumento alla difesa di Casale, Piazza Castello, Casale Monferrato (Ian Spackman 199xC n25).jpg|thumb|200px|Bronze of a young female warrior in [[Lombards|Lombard]] costume. Francesco Porzio, ''Monumento alla difesa di Casale'', 1897]] A '''virago''' is a woman who demonstrates exemplary and heroic qualities. The word comes from the Latin word ''virāgō'' (([[genitive case|genitive]] virāginis) meaning variously 'a man-like, vigorous, heroic maiden, a female warrior, heroine..'{{L&S|virago|virāgō|ref}} from ''vir'' meaning 'man' (cf. [[virile]] and [[virtue]]) to which the suffix ''-āgō '' is added, a suffix that creates a new noun of the [[Third declension|third declension]] with feminine [[grammatical gender]]. The word ''virago'' has almost always had an association with cultural [[gender role|gender transgression]]. A virago, of whatever excellence, was still identified by her gender. There are recorded instances of viragos (such as [[Joan of Arc]]) fighting battles, wearing men's clothing, or receiving the [[tonsure]].Jane Tibbetts Schulenburg. ''Forgetful of their sex: female sanctity and society, ca. 500-1100''. University Of Chicago Press, 2001. Page 50. {{ISBN|978-0-226-74054-6}}. The word ''virago'' could also be used disparagingly, to imply that a virago was not excellent or heroic, but was instead violating cultural norms. Thus ''virago'' joined [[pejorative]]s such as ''[[termagant]]'',{{Cite web| url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/virago| title=Virago| accessdate=2011-11-25| publisher=Merriam-Webster Online}} ''mannish'', ''amazonian'' and ''[[Shrew (archetype)|shrew]]'' to demean women who acted aggressively or like men. ==History== Historically, the concept of a virago reaches back into antiquity where [[Hellenistic philosophy]] asserted that elite and exceptionally heroic men had ''[[virtus (virtue)|virtus]]'' ({{lang-el|ἀνδρεία|andreia}}). ''Virtus'' (once again linked to ''vir'', the brave man abiding by society's highest values and ethics as opposed to ''homo'', human being) defined the traits of excellence for a man in ancient Rome (and Greece), including valor and heroism, but also morality and physical strength. Women and non-elite or unheroic men (slaves, servants, craftsmen, merchants) were considered a lesser category, and believed to be less excellent in [[Mos maiorum|Roman morality]]. A woman, however, if exceptional enough could earn the title ''virago''. In doing so, she surpassed the expectations for what was believed possible for her [[gender]], and embodied masculine-like aggressionVirginia Blanton. ''Signs of devotion: the cult of St. Æthelthryth in medieval England, 695-1615'' Pennsylvania State Univ Pr (Trd) (April 30, 2007). Page 168. {{ISBN|978-0-271-02984-9}}. and/or excellence. Virago, then, was a title of respect and admiration. In [[Christianity]], a [[nun]] or holy woman who had become equal in divinity to male [[monks]] through practiced [[celibacy]], exemplary religious practice and devotion, and intact [[virginity]], was considered to have surpassed the limitations of her femaleness and was called ''virago''.Newman, Barbara. ''From Virile Woman to Woman Christ: Studies in Medieval Religion and Literature''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1995. Page 5. {{ISBN|978-0-8122-1545-8}}.Laurence Lux-Sterritt. Redefining Female Religious Life: French Ursulines And English Ladies in Seventeenth-Century Catholicism. Ashgate Pub Co (January 30, 2006). Page 61. {{ISBN|978-0-7546-3716-5}}. Firmicus Maternus describes virago as women who take on a man's character and desire intercourse with women like men.{{Cite book|title=Love Between Women: early Christian responses to female homoeroticism|last=Brooten|first=Bernadette|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|year=1996|isbn=978-0-226-07591-4|location=Chicago|pages=135}} Standard modern dictionaries define ''virago'' as either, in order of definition, (1) a "loud overbearing woman"; a "shrew".{Merriam-Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language Unabridged, Copyright (c) 1993 Merriam-Webster, Incorporated, first definition of "virago"} or (2) a woman of "great stature, strength, and courage"http://www.answers.com/topic/virago Thus virago continues to be associated with both the naming of a woman who has either (1) a domineering, abrasive and spiteful manner, or (2) has risen above cultural and [[sexism|gender stereotypes]] to embody a [[virility|virile]] heroism; for example, the [[British Royal Navy]] christened at least four warships ''[[HMS Virago|Virago]]''. ==Vulgate Bible== The [[Vulgate]] Bible, translated by [[Jerome]] and others in the 4th century C.E., was an early Latin translation of the Hebrew Bible [[Hebrew Bible|Old Testament]]. In Genesis 2:23, Jerome uses the words ''Vir'' for man and ''Virago'' for "woman" attempting to reproduce a pun on "male" and "female" (''ish'' and ''ishah'') that existed in the Hebrew text.Saint Jerome, Robert Hayward. ''Saint Jerome's Hebrew questions on Genesis.'' Oxford University Press, USA (August 10, 1995) Page 113. {{ISBN|978-0-19-826350-0}}Helen Kraus. ''Gender Issues in Ancient and Reformation Translations of Genesis 1-4.'' Oxford University Press, USA (December 17, 2011). Page 182. {{ISBN|978-0-19-960078-6}} The Vulgate reads:
''Dixitque Adam hoc nunc os ex ossibus meis et caro de carne mea haec vocabitur '''virago''' quoniam de viro sumpta est.''
"And Adam said: This now is bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called woman, because she was taken out of man."
The Middle English poem ''[[Cursor Mundi]]'' retains the Latin name for the woman in its otherwise Middle English account of the creation:
''Quen sco was broght be-for adam, '''Virago''' he gaf her to nam; þar for hight sco '''virago''', ffor maked of the man was sco.'' (lines 631–34)
"When she was brought before Adam, Virago was the name he gave to her; Therefore she is called Virago, For she was made out of the man."
==See also== {{wiktionary|virago}} * [[Amazons]] * [[Sexual slur]] * [[Tomboy]] * [[Women warriors in literature and culture|Woman warrior]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== *Ernst Breisach, ''[[Caterina Sforza]] ; A Renaissance virago'', Chicago [usw.]: University Press 1967 *Elizabeth D. Carney,"[[Olympias]] and the Image of the Virago" in: Phoenix, Vol. 47, No. 1 (Spring, 1993), pp. 29–55 *Morris, Richard. ''[[Cursor Mundi]]: A Northumbrian Poem of the XIV Century.'' London: Oxford UP, 1874. Republished 1961. *Barbara Newman. ''From virile woman to womanChrist: studies in medieval religion and literature''. University of Pennsylvania Press (January 1, 1995) * Jane Tibbetts Schulenburg. ''Forgetful of their sex: female sanctity and society, ca. 500-1100''. University Of Chicago Press (January 1, 2001) *Yenna Wu, ''The Chinese virago : a literary theme'', Cambridge, Mass. [u.a.] : Harvard Univ. Press, 1995 [[Category:Gender]] [[Category:Women in war]] [[Category:Christianity and women]] [[Category:Feminism and the arts]] [[Category:Pejorative terms for people]] [[Category:Misogynistic slurs]]

revision.comment: /* Synopsis */ Corrected a minor syntactical mistake
revision.text:
'''Virgilius the Sorcerer''' is a [[fairy tale]] about the poet [[Virgil]] by [[Andrew Lang]] who included it in ''[[The Violet Fairy Book]]''. ==Virgil's powers== Medieval legends attributed [[magic (paranormal)|magical]] powers to the poet [[Virgil#Mysticism and hidden meanings|Virgil]], but even among these legends, this tale attributes a very high level of power to him. Among his accomplishments in the tale, Virgilius is a quick thinker, using his magical powers to defeat corruption and military attacks and spirits. One of his spells was to make an army immobile, turn men to stone, or create a river out of nowhere, encircling them so they could not proceed. Although he wins many challenges, including a magician's battle, wily schemes also help his cause. Among his creations, he invents and animates a horse, rider and dogs out of copper to assert his will. Virgilius avenges the trickery of his first love for publicly humiliating him before finding true love at last, and creating the city of [[Naples]] for her. ==Synopsis== The story begins –
Long, long ago there was born to a Roman knight and his wife Maja a little boy called Virgilius. While he was still quite little, his father died, and the kinsmen, instead of being a help and protection to the child and his mother, robbed them of their lands and money, and the widow, fearing that they might take the boy's life also, sent him away to [[Spain]], that he might study in the great University of [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]].
One holiday, when walking, he came upon an evil spirit that was trapped; the spirit offered him magical books in exchange for setting him free. Virgilius demanded the books, and the knowledge how to use them, first; then he freed the spirit. It grew to an enormous size, so the quick-witted Virgilius declared he did not believe it came out of the hole, and the spirit, to prove it, went back in whereupon Virgilius quickly trapped it again. He studied magic for many days gaining a wonderful reputation for his powers ("he was much thought of as showing promise of great learning"). This was cut short when his mother sent for him because she was ill and could no longer look after their affairs. When he arrived home, his rich relatives were displeased because his presence meant they could no longer rob their kinsmen. They were, however, related to the emperor, who put off the matter of giving Virgilius his due. His enemies attacked him but Virgilius used his magic to drive them off or cast spells on them. The emperor himself went to him without effect until a magician came into camp and was hired to battle Virgilius. Virgilius had a hard time fighting the magician, but reached the emperor in secret with a proposition: he would stop the fight if he could have justice, compelling the emperor to agree. Virgilius then fell in love with a woman named Febilla. She told him that she would let him visit her by drawing him up in a basket to a tower. Once he was in the basket, she lifted it only half way, leaving him a dangling target of the crowd's ridicule. The emperor ordered his release, but the next day, no fire in Rome would light. Virgilius told them to bring Febilla to a scaffold in the market place and take fire from her. Fire started about her and she had to stand there until everyone had re-lit their fires. The emperor threw Virgilius into prison with a death sentence, but when he was brought up, thirsty Virgilius asked for water. When the guards brought him a pail of water, Virgilius jumped into it, saying he was going to Sicily and magically vanished. Andrew Lang has heavily bowdlerized his sources here; in the original Medieval tradition, the fire could only be rekindled from her vagina. The story was very popular with Renaissance artists. The [[Metropolitan Museum]] has a Venetian ''confittiera'' (ca. 1475–1500) showing Febilla standing on the square with raised skirt, a gift by [[J. Pierpont Morgan]].[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/arlo/ho_17.190.730a,b.htm Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History][http://alaintruong.canalblog.com/archives/2008/11/23/11465448.html Les cahiers d'Alain Truong] ===Effects on Rome=== The fairy tale says that it is unknown how he reconciled with the emperor, but he next made statues of the gods of every country, including Rome, with bells in their hands, and the bells would ring if they intended treachery toward Rome, so the Romans would send their armies against them. A country that hated them sent men to Rome; they claimed to be diviners and to have dreamed of gold, and then, with the Senate's permission, dug up the gold they had buried the night before. The [[Rule of three (writing)|third]] time, they told the Senate it was under the Capitol and they would dig for them, for their generosity; they undermined the Capitol and stole away. Immediately after, the statues fell and were ruined. Much crime followed in the city. Virgilius had a copper horse and rider made and ordered all men indoors. Only the honest obeyed, and the horse trampled those it found outside. The next day, the surviving thieves tried to use ropes and grapples to stop it, and used rope ladders to escape it. Two copper dogs were added, to jump up and bite them to death. Virgilius fell in love with a foreign princess, the daughter of a sultan, and carried her away from her father. She was a guest in his house, wondering at the marvels, until she wished to return to her father. Virgilius returned her, but the sultan ordered his death. Virgilius cast a spell on him and his court and carried the princess away again. Then, thinking Rome not fine enough, he built a marvelous city for her, which was [[Naples]]. ==Commentary== The technique of tricking spirit is a motif also found in ''[[The Spirit in the Bottle]]'' and with genies in ''[[The Fisherman and the Jinni]]''. The legend that he had been trapped in a basket was a common medieval tale, warning of the power of love to make fools of men. There is a reference to the "Black Book" he uses as the source of his spells which in popular culture can be a book containing lists or evil deeds. ==References== *[http://www.mythfolklore.net/andrewlang/050.htm ''Virgililus the Sorcerer''] {{Reflist}} [[Category:Fairy tales]]

revision.text:
{{about|the social event|the dance style|Melbourne Shuffle}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} [[File:Torontozombiewalk.jpg|thumb|250px|A 2012 zombie walk in [[Toronto]]]] {{zombies}} A '''zombie walk''' is an organized public gathering of people who dress up in [[zombie]] costumes. Participants usually meet in an urban center and make their way around the city streets and public spaces (or a series of taverns in the case of a '''zombie pub crawl''') in an orderly fashion. Zombie walks can be organized simply for entertainment or with a purpose, such as setting a [[world record]] or promoting a charitable cause. Originating in North America during the 2000s, zombie walks have occurred throughout the world.
==Format== Zombie walks are relatively common in large cities, especially in North America. Some have been established as annual traditions, though others are organized as spontaneous [[flash mob]] events or [[performance art]]. The complexity and purpose of zombie walks varies. As an advanced technique to heighten interest and realism, some zombie mobs will "eat" victims to create new zombies, in sight of onlookers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2728235416012736070&ei=0_30SPSTBoSKqQPfpc0B&q=sf+zombie+mob+2005 |title=Zombies attack willing "bystanders" |publisher=Google |date=July 30, 2005 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124022356/http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2728235416012736070&ei=0_30SPSTBoSKqQPfpc0B&q=sf+zombie+mob+2005 |archivedate=January 24, 2009 }}</ref> Some participants occasionally dress up as soldiers who are called in to contain the outbreak, or survivors who are trying to defend themselves from the onslaught of the zombie horde. Some events are staged as spoof [[Demonstration (people)|political rallies]] organized "to raise awareness of zombie rights", with participants carrying placards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/arts/articulate/200604/s1627099.htm |title=ABC News: They came, they saw, they lurched |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=April 30, 2006 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> Some zombie walks have also been staged as "[[hunger marches]]" with the intent of raising awareness of [[world hunger]] and collecting items for [[food bank]]s.<ref name="dailyiowan1">{{cite web |url=http://www.dailyiowan.com/2009/09/21/Metro/13034.html |title=Iowa City's fourth-annual Zombie Walk collects a record-breaking number |work=[[The Daily Iowan]] |date=September 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> {{clear left}} [[File:Zombie Walk Toronto 2011.jpg|thumb|A zombie wearing a 'mock' political shirt during a Zombie Walk in [[Toronto]], 2011.]] ==History==
===Gencon 2000=== '''The earliest zombie walk styled event on record''' was put together rather last-minute at the [[Gen Con]] gaming convention in [[Milwaukee]] in August 2000. The event was created to poke good-natured fun at the ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]'' [[LARP]]ers that were taking over large portions of the convention, and disrupt their games. Michael Yates, Mark Stafford, Jacob Skowronek and several others organized the event with roughly 60 participants. The event was later recorded in the book ''40 Years of Gencon''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Laws|first1=Robin D.|title=40 Years of Gencon|isbn=1589780973}}</ref> with photos and recollections from the organizers. While it was rumored that the organizers were arrested and thrown out of the convention for their flash mob of zombies, they were simply questioned by security before being told to disband.
===Annual Trash Film Orgy film festival=== Another early zombie walk was held in [[Sacramento, California]] on August 19, 2001.<ref name="RedfernSteiger2014">{{cite book|author1=Nick Redfern|author2=Brad Steiger|title=The Zombie Book: The Encyclopedia of the Living Dead|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=94QsBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT613|date=18 August 2014|publisher=Visible Ink Press|isbn=978-1-57859-531-0|page=613}}</ref><ref name="McDonald2013">{{cite book|author=Megan McDonald|title=Stink and the Midnight Zombie Walk|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=97kojzX8njIC&pg=PA127|date=12 February 2013|publisher=Candlewick Press|isbn=978-0-7636-6422-0|page=127}}</ref><ref name="PaffenrothMorehead2012">{{cite book|author1=Kim Paffenroth|author2=John W. Morehead|title=The Undead and Theology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OVdNAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA102|date=21 September 2012|publisher=Wipf and Stock Publishers|isbn=978-1-61097-875-0|page=102}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/content?oid=8668 |title=Arts and Entertainment: Writer's Choice |work=[[Sacramento News & Review]] |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref>
The event, billed as "The Zombie Parade", was the idea of Bryna Lovig, who suggested it to the organizers of Trash Film Orgy<ref name="tfoproductions.com">{{cite web|url=http://tfoproductions.com|title=TFO Productions|publisher=TFO Productions}}</ref> as a way to promote their annual midnight film festival.<ref name="PulliamFonseca2014">{{cite book|author1=June Michele Pulliam|author2=Anthony J. Fonseca|title=Encyclopedia of the Zombie: The Walking Dead in Popular Culture and Myth: The Walking Dead in Popular Culture and Myth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=52NyBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA318|date=19 June 2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-4408-0389-5|page=318}}</ref> It was held again on July 27, 2002, and has since become an annual event,<ref name="PulliamFonseca2014" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/content?oid=12731 |title=Friends, seen and unseen |work=[[Sacramento News & Review]] |date=July 25, 2002 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> drawing over 1,000 participants in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sacbee.com/2012/07/13/4625180/zombie-walk-kicks-off-sacramentos.html |title=Zombie Walk kicks off Sacramento's Trash Film Orgy |work=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |date=July 13, 2012 |accessdate=August 27, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718025301/http://www.sacbee.com/2012/07/13/4625180/zombie-walk-kicks-off-sacramentos.html |archive-date=July 18, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The event was traditionally held as the kick off to the six-week film festival at Sacramento's historic [[Crest Theatre]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Meyer|first1=Carla|title=This year's trash films have their share of delights|url=http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/movies-news-reviews/article2603309.html|accessdate=26 February 2015|agency=McClathcy News|publisher=Sacramento bee|date=July 10, 2014}}</ref> until 2014 when the theatre's general manager of 28 years, Laura "Sid" Garcia-Heberger, couldn't reach a lease renewal agreement with the building owners.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Meyer|first1=Carla|title=Crest’s longtime manager to end run on up note|url=http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/movies-news-reviews/article2835148.html|accessdate=26 February 2015|agency=McClatchy News|publisher=Sacramento Bee|date=October 16, 2014}}</ref>
Despite the film festival's change of venue, TFO continues the walk as part of a free all-ages event, the "Carnival of the Dead", which includes [[food truck]]s from local vendors, make up stations, live bands, contests, games, and a projected movie in the park at the end of the night.<ref>{{cite news|title=Zombies to terrorize R Street for 15th year|publisher=Sacramento Bee|date=26 August 2015|url=http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/article32465130.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=TFO Zombie Walk & Carnival of the Dead|url=http://sacramento.downtowngrid.com/listings/tfo-zombie-walk-carnival-of-the-dead/|accessdate=26 February 2015|agency=Downtown Sacramento Grid|publisher=Sacramento grid|date=July 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sacramento Zombie Walk|url=http://saczombiewalk.com}}</ref> The streets in downtown Sacramento comprising the walk's route are shut down by the city in order to safely accommodate the large numbers of participants.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sacramento/news/2014/05/29/preparing-for-zombies-city-to-ward-off-crush-of.html|title=Preparing for zombies: City to ward off crush of undead by closing streets}}</ref>
===Toronto and Sherbrooke walk=== '''The first gathering specifically billed as a "Zombie Walk" occurred in October 2003 in [[Toronto]],'''<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0oZIlm84F2oC&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=better+off+dead+sarah+lauro+toronto+zombie+walk&source=bl&ots=OqJbMv2GXk&sig=qyIEewwwnm7-8Mau9e4VpwWN7Ac&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D6K7UY3RMtPOqwH7-IGIBA&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=better%20off%20dead%20sarah%20lauro%20toronto%20zombie%20walk&f=false |title=Chapter 3: Zombies Invade Performance Art...And Your Neighborhood – Better Off Dead: The Evolution of the Zombie As Post Human |publisher=[[Fordham University Press]] |year=2011 |accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref> organized by local horror movie fan Thea Munster and with only seven participants.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/stream/Exd-volume04-Issue01/Volume4Issue01#page/n9/mode/1up|title= Zombie Walk 2003 |publisher=Equalizing X Distort Blogspot |accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref> A "zombie demonstration" occurred in [[Sherbrooke]], [[Quebec]], on November 1, 2003, organized by a local grassroots organization, with 60 participants walking on a one kilometer course downtown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archives-2001-2012.cmaq.net/es/node/14119.html |title=Manifestation des Zombies contre le néo-libéralisme |publisher=CMAQ.net |date=November 3, 2003 |accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> Another zombie march was organized the next year by the same group in Sherbrooke, with nearly 200 participants. In subsequent years, the Toronto Zombie Walk has grown tremendously in size, with the 2014 event playing host to more than 15,000 participants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blogto.com/city/2009/10/toronto_zombie_walk_2009/ |title=Toronto Zombie Walk 2009 |publisher=Blogto.com |date=October 26, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> The Zombie Walk has spread to [[Vancouver]], creating the zombie walk tradition in that city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vancouverhalloween.com/vh_ZombieWalk.html |title=Vancouver Halloween Vancouver Zombie Walk |publisher=Vancouverhalloween.com |date=July 16, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613172144/http://www.vancouverhalloween.com/vh_ZombieWalk.html |archivedate=June 13, 2008}}</ref> On August 27, 2005, over 400 participants proceeded through Vancouver's [[Pacific Centre]] mall, travelled on the [[SkyTrain (Vancouver)|SkyTrain]] (referred to for the event as the "SkyBrain" or the "BrainTrain"), and continued 35 blocks to [[Mountain View Cemetery (Vancouver)|Mountain View Cemetery]].
===Gaining popularity=== The mid to late 2000s saw an exponential gain in popularity for zombie walks, due largely to the success of [[zombie films]] at the time, such as the [[Resident Evil (film)|''Resident Evil'' movies]], ''[[28 Days Later]]'', [[Zack Snyder]]'s ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'', ''[[Shaun of the Dead]]'', [[George A. Romero]]'s ''[[Land of the Dead]]'', and ''[[Zombieland]]''. Documentation of zombie walks consequently began to appear more often in [[Mainstream media|mainstream news media]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2009-10-09/features/0910080095_1_zombie-undead-walk |title=A Chance To Get In Touch With Your Inner Zombie |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |date=October 9, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> and blogs. Zombie walks soon spread across North America and to cities around the globe, such as [[Mar del Plata]], Argentina.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://goringa.net/post/imgenes/5035/zombie-walk-mar-del-plata-2011.html |title=Zombie Walk Mar Del Plata 2011 |publisher=Goringa! |accessdate=July 25, 2011}}</ref> [[Rio de Janeiro]] had its first zombie walk on November 2, 2007 ([[Day of the Dead]]) and the event has become annual since then.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://g1.globo.com/rio-de-janeiro/noticia/2012/11/no-dia-de-finados-jovens-se-vestem-de-zumbis-na-praia-de-copacabana.html |title=No Dia de Finados jovens se vestem de zumbis na Praia de Copacabana |language=Portuguese |publisher=Organizações Globo |accessdate=November 2, 2012}}</ref>
On October 29, 2006, nearly 900 "zombie walkers" gathered at the [[Monroeville Mall]] outside of [[Pittsburgh]], which served as the set of George A. Romero's classic zombie film ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'', to participate in Pittsburgh's first annual Walk of the Dead.<ref name="post-gazette2006">Donaldson, Bob, and Roberts, Larry. [http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06303/734088-56.stm A walk with zombies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126200047/http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06303/734088-56.stm |date=November 26, 2011 }} (Online multimedia presentation.) Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. October 30, 2006.</ref> In addition to setting a [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]], the event was a benefit for the Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank. Pittsburgh's zombie walk has since grown into an annual horror [[Fan convention|festival]] called Zombie Fest and organized by ''The It's Alive Show'', a local Pittsburgh late night horror and science fiction television program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theitsaliveshow.com/zombiefest2008/wzd.htm |title=About Zombie Fest and World Zombie Day |work=The It's Alive Show |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> The Pittsburgh festival plays host to the annual Walk of the Dead as well as a zombie [[ball (dance)|ball]], costume contest, concerts, and celebrity guest appearances, and also serves as the headquarters of ''The It's Alive Show''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s World Zombie Day, a world hunger charity event.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/worldzombieday |title=MySpace-blog | van WORLD ZOMBIE DAY |publisher=Myspace |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707064747/http://blogs.myspace.com/worldzombieday |archive-date=July 7, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Zombie walks are also a regular occurrence at ZomBcon, "the world's first zombie convention" which takes place every October in [[Seattle]]. Apart from zombie walks, ZomBcon also features panel discussions with zombie authors, actors and artists, workshops, film screenings, and other activities for zombie [[Fan (person)|fans]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.movieviral.com/2011/04/06/can-you-survive-zombcon-the-worlds-first-zombie-convention/ |title=Can You Survive ZomBcon, The World’s First Zombie Convention? |publisher=MovieViral.com |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> ZomBcon also organizes Seattle's annual Red, White and Dead zombie walk every July.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zombcon.com/ |title=zomBcon.com |publisher=ZomBcon |accessdate=April 7, 2010}}</ref> {{clear}}
===World records=== [[File:Zombie walk Pittsburgh 29 Oct 2006.png|thumb|Official [[Monroeville Mall]] world record attempt photo in 2006]]
The first zombie walk world record was set on October 29, 2006 at Monroeville Mall outside of Pittsburgh, during the city's first annual Walk of the Dead. Guinness World Records certified that 894 people participated in the walk.<ref name="post-gazette2006"/> The second zombie walk at Monroeville Mall during the 2007 Zombie Fest was also verified by Guinness World Records as the largest gathering of zombies to date, with 1,028 participants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theitsaliveshow.com/toppage3.htm |title=News & Events |publisher=The It's Alive Show |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref>
The 2007 Toronto Zombie Walk drew a crowd of over 1,100 zombies, a number confirmed by Toronto Police Services.<ref name="pennyblood.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.pennyblood.com/zombiewalk1.html |title=Toronto Zombie Walk |publisher=Penny Blood |date=October 21, 2007 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906054540/http://www.pennyblood.com/zombiewalk1.html |archivedate=September 6, 2009 }}</ref> At the time, this was the largest zombie walk on record.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/multimedia/camera-club/toronto-zombie-walk/article1771337/ |title=Toronto Zombie Walk |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=October 25, 2010 |accessdate=July 25, 2011}}</ref> A zombie march in [[Brisbane]] on May 25, 2008 set an unofficial record of over 1,500 participants, according to media reports.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/articles/2008/05/25/1211653837812.html?from=top5 |title=Undead take over city |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> On June 21, 2008, a zombie march took place in [[Chicago]] with over 1,550 zombies estimated, setting a new unofficial record.<ref>{{cite web |date=June 23, 2008 |url=http://www.undeadreport.com/2008/06/zombies-attack-downtown-chicago/ |title=Zombies Attack Downtown Chicago |publisher=Undead Report |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Zombie walk 08 Nottingham.jpg|thumb|left|[[Nottingham]] Zombie Walk in 2008]]
On October 31, 2008, a zombie walk took place in the Old Market Square of [[Nottingham]], England, with 1,227 attendees. The event was organized by [[GameCity]], and the zombies did dances to zombie-related songs such as "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Disturbia (song)|Disturbia]]", and "[[Ghostbusters (song)|Ghostbusters]]", and featured a performance from American singer [[Jonathan Coulton]]. The event achieved a new official Guinness World Record for largest zombie walk.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gamecity.org/2008/10/zombies-march-on-gamecity/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223193545/http://gamecity.org/2008/10/zombies-march-on-gamecity/ |archivedate=February 23, 2009 |title=Zombies March on GameCity! |publisher=[[GameCity]] |date=February 23, 2009 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> In June 2009, Pittsburgh zombie fans won back the Guinness World Record after Guinness verified that the Zombie Fest 'Walk of the Dead' at Monroeville Mall on October 26, 2008, had 1,341 participating walkers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mediathatchangeslives.com/tv/onq/onq_schedule.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123102149/http://mediathatchangeslives.com/tv/onq/onq_schedule.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-01-23|title=WQED Multimedia: OnQ Schedule|date=2010-01-23|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref>
On July 3, 2009, a zombie walk organized by [[Fremont, Seattle|Fremont]] Outdoor Movies in Seattle beat all previous zombie walk records. Guinness World Records officially recorded 3,894 zombies at the Red, White and Dead zombie event,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/archives/174438.asp |title=Now it's official: Guinness to certify record Seattle zombie walk |publisher=Blog.seattlepi.com |date= July 23, 2009|accessdate=January 28, 2010 |first=Monica |last=Guzman}}</ref> though local news claimed 4277 participants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kirotv.com/news/19997248/detail.html |title=Seattle Breaks Zombie Record |publisher=[[KIRO-TV]] |date=July 8, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/archives/173248.asp |title=Organizers: Seattle breaks world record for walking zombies |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=July 8, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |first=Monica |last=Guzman}}</ref> In October 2009, Guinness World Records officially recorded and approved a new record for the largest gathering of zombies. The record was set at the Big Chill Festival in [[Ledbury]], England, on August 6, 2009. There were 4,026 zombie mob participants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://community.guinnessworldrecords.com/_Zombie-Mayhem/photo/6250791/7691.html |title=Zombie Mayhem! – United Kingdom, Guinness World Records Photo |publisher=[[Guinness World Records]] |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716121220/http://community.guinnessworldrecords.com/_Zombie-Mayhem/photo/6250791/7691.html |archive-date=July 16, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 25, 2009, the biggest recorded gathering of zombies in the [[Southern Hemisphere]] occurred in Brisbane, with over 5,000 participants reportedly in attendance as reported by the [[Queensland Police]]. The walk was also a charity event helping to raise awareness and money for the Brain Foundation of Australia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/10/29/2727378.htm |title=Grave concerns over Brisbane zombie plague |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=October 29, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2011}}</ref> On October 30, 2009, zombie walkers in [[Grand Rapids]], [[Michigan]] attempted a second run at the zombie mob world record. An estimated 8,000 participants braved rainy weather to gather in Calder Plaza outside of Grand Rapids's City and County buildings. The event was coordinated by Rob Bliss, organizer of Grand Rapids's first zombie walk. Volunteers collected signatures from the crowd, though the record is currently unverified by Guinness.<ref>{{cite web |first=Katy |last=Batdorff |work=[[The Grand Rapids Press]] |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/10/rain_unable_to_stop_grand_rapi.html |title=Rain unable to stop Grand Rapids Zombie Walk, estimated 8,000 invade downtown |publisher=[[Mlive.com]] |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> Organizers of the fifth annual Denver Zombie Crawl in [[Denver]] counted more than 7,300 zombie walkers in the event. This is considered to be a low figure, as up to one third of the total participants did not walk through the counter. The crawl took place on October 23, 2010, in downtown Denver at the [[16th Street Mall]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/video/player/0,32068,653378918001_0,00.html |title=Zombies in Denver Crawl for a New World Record |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=October 31, 2010 |accessdate=October 31, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/25/denver-zombie-crawl-meets_n_773752.html |title=Denver Zombie Crawl Meets Expectations, Sets New World Record |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=October 25, 2010 |accessdate=October 25, 2010 |first=Ethan |last=Axelrod}}</ref> On October 24, 2010, a reported 10,000-strong zombie walk took place in Brisbane. As with previous years, the event raised money for the Brain Foundation of Australia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/thousands-of-undead-dance-and-shuffle-through-brisbane-20101025-16ziq.html |title=Brisbane Zombie Walk: Pictures, Photos | Brisbane Zombie Walk 2010 |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |date=October 25, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:New Jersey Zombie Walk.JPG|thumb|[[New Jersey]] Zombie Walk in 2010]]
Guinness officially recognized a new record for the world's largest gathering of zombies on October 30, 2010, at the third annual New Jersey Zombie Walk on the Asbury Park Boardwalk in [[Asbury Park]]. Guinness recorded 4,093 zombies at the event, though organizers, police, and fire officials estimate more than 5,000 zombies were in attendance.<ref>{{cite news |last=Monda |first=Michael |title=Zombies invade Asbury Park to set Guinness World Record |url=http://videos.nj.com/star-ledger/2010/10/zombies_invade_asbury_park_to.html |accessdate=October 31, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=October 31, 2010}}</ref>
In July 2011, more cities would attempt to break this world record. On July 2, 2011, Seattle attempted to take back the record at the 3rd annual Fremont Red, White and Dead Zombie Walk hosted by Fremont Outdoor Movies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zombcon.com |title=zomBcon |publisher=zomBcon |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> The zombie count according to Fremont organizers was 4,522<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/2011/07/03/photos-red-white-dead-zombie-walk-in-fremont/ | title=Photos: Red White & Dead Zombie Walk in Fremont |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | first=Joshua | last=Trujillo |date=July 3, 2011}}</ref> in attendance with estimations of over 4,800–5,000 after the official stop point for counting zombies. Representatives from Guinness did not attend the event. On July 23, 2011, the Dublin Zombie Walk<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dublinzombiewalk.com |title=Dublin Zombie Walk |publisher=Dublin Zombie Walk |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> in [[Dublin]] had an estimated 8,000 zombies in attendance, but confirmation is still pending from Guinness World Records.
October 2011 also saw multiple attempts to break the New Jersey world record. Over 7,000 zombies are believed to have attended the 9th Annual Toronto Zombie Walk on October 22.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/10/22/zombie-walk-to-matrimonial-bliss |title=Zombie Walk to matrimonial bliss |work=[[Toronto Sun]] |date=October 22, 2011 |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> Both the annual Denver Zombie Crawl on October 22<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_19174011 |title=Zombies live the screams on Denver's 16th Street Mall Crawl |work=[[The Denver Post]] |date=October 23, 2011 |accessdate=October 23, 2011 |first=Weston |last=Gentry}}</ref> and the annual Brisbane Zombie Walk on October 23<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.abc.net.au/queensland/2011/10/brisbanes-zombie-walk-smashes-previous-world-record.html |title=Brisbane's Zombie Walk smashes previous world record |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=October 24, 2011 |accessdate=October 24, 2011}}</ref> claim to have had over 12,000 zombie participants. On October 29, the city of [[Long Beach, California]], set out to break the world record as part of its fourth annual zombie walk, produced by community organizations Long Beach Cinematheque and Mondo Celluloid, and partnered with [[Michael Jackson]]-inspired flash mob "[[Thrill the World]]", who set out to break a world record of their own with the world's biggest "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]" flash mob. By night's end, an estimated 14,000 participants had taken over the entirety of the downtown area, breaking local business sales records and all but shutting down traffic for hours.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} In November 2011, [[Mexico City]] counted 9,806 for their large zombie gathering.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20111126/mexico-city-zombie-walk-record-111126/ |publisher=[[CTV Television Network|CTV]] |title='Ghouls' gather in Mexico to break 'Zombie Walk' record |date=November 26, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2013}}</ref>
The zombie walk of October 20, 2012 in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] had more than 12,000 zombies walking in the city, though no Guinness record was broken.<ref>{{cite web |first=Hazel |last=Chua |url=http://fashionablygeek.com/costumes/santiagos-zombie-walk-draws-out-12000-of-the-living-dead-video/ |title=Santiago's Zombie Walk Draws Out 12,000 of the Living Dead |publisher=FashionablyGeek.com |date=October 24, 2012 |accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> On October 28, 2012, [[Buenos Aires]] gathered 25,000 zombies.<ref>{{cite web |first=Leandro Avalos |last=Blacha |url=http://www.revistaenie.clarin.com/escenarios/Buenos-Aires-invadida-por-los-muertos-vivos_0_800920101.html |title=Buenos Aires, invadida por los muertos vivos |language=Spanish |publisher=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]] |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
The zombie walk occurring November 2012, in the Twin Cities ([[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]]) holds the current world record for zombie gathering, recognized by Guinness at a count of 8,027 at [[Midway Stadium]] in Saint Paul on October 13, 2012. Estimates of the entire Twin Cities crawl put the zombie event upwards of 30,000 zombie participates, surpassing any other gathering of its kind, official or not.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2012/11/zombie_pub_crawl_breaks_guinness_world_record.php|title=Zombie Pub Crawl breaks world record|author=Andy Mannix|date=November 14, 2012|work=The Blotter|accessdate=February 28, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150501150437/http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2012/11/zombie_pub_crawl_breaks_guinness_world_record.php|archive-date=May 1, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2013, the Asbury Park event reclaimed the world record with 9,592 zombies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/monmouth/index.ssf/2013/10/photos_zombies_invade_asbury_park_in_search_of_world_record.html|title=PHOTOS: Zombies invade Asbury Park to set Guinness World Record|work=NJ.com|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref> In October 19, 2013 an estimated 15,000 [[People of Chile|Chileans]] took to the streets of [[Santiago]] to take part in the city's fourth annual Zombie Walk. The zombies limped two kilometres along the [[Avenida Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins|Alameda]], one of the main thoroughfares in the Chilean capital.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/10392072/Zombies-walk-the-streets-of-Santiago.html |title=Zombies walk the streets of Santiago |work=Daily Telegraph |author= |date=October 30, 2013 |accessdate=January 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229200719/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/10392072/Zombies-walk-the-streets-of-Santiago.html |archivedate=December 29, 2016 |df=mdy}}</ref>
'''''South Brazil'''''
The Zombie Walk, annually held in Curitiba, South Brazil, it's known to bear 15,000 to 25,000 zombies and people. Held during the Brazilian Carnival holidays, Curitiba is known to be not much fond of the famous Brazilian festivity preferring instead to host the Psycho Carnival rock festival in which the Zombie Walk was derived off. Many people from states who also do not like samba or the carnival associated acts go to Curitiba for the Zombie Walk and rock festivals around the city.
==Charity events== Charity work continues to be a common component of zombie walks across the planet.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zombieorama.com |title=Zombie-O-Rama Home |publisher=Zombieorama.com |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/your-brisbane/zombies-plan-weekend-invasion-20091019-h467.html |title=Zombies plan weekend invasion |publisher=[[Brisbane Times]] |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marshalltownzombies.com |title=Marshalltown Zombies |publisher=Marshalltown Zombies |accessdate=May 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312022749/http://www.marshalltownzombies.com/ |archive-date=March 12, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Community service organizations such as [[Zombie Squad]] have used zombie walks as demonstrations to raise funds and awareness for local and global issues, such as world hunger.<ref name="dailyiowan1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.thegrandviews.com/media/storage/paper1329/news/2008/10/31/News/Zombies.Roam.Halls.Of.Dorms.In.Search.Of.Food-3515993.shtml |title=Zombies roam halls of dorms in search of food |publisher=thegrandviews.com |date=October 18, 2007 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717001518/http://media.www.thegrandviews.com/media/storage/paper1329/news/2008/10/31/News/Zombies.Roam.Halls.Of.Dorms.In.Search.Of.Food-3515993.shtml |archivedate=July 17, 2011 }}</ref>
Both world record walks at Pittsburgh's Zombie Fest have included food drives. In 2008, ''The It's Alive Show'' initiated World Zombie Day.<ref name="myspace1">{{cite web |url=http://www.myspace.com/worldzombieday |title=World Zombie Day |publisher=MySpace |date=September 25, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> ''The It's Alive Show'' encouraged cities all over the globe to celebrate World Zombie Day by holding zombie walks to raise awareness of global hunger. The first World Zombie Day took place October 26, 2008, the same day as Pittsburgh's Zombie Fest, when more than 30 cities worldwide took part. [[drive (charity)|Food drives]] for local hunger-related charities took place at each participating city's zombie walk. Pittsburgh's walk alone brought in more than one ton of food to benefit the Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.incommunitymagazines.com/monroeville/read.asp?artid=519|title=Zombie walk {{!}} IN Community Magazines|date=2011-11-13|access-date=2017-10-12}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}</ref> The second World Zombie Day took place October 11, 2009, with even more participation from cities all over the world.<ref name="myspace1"/>
October 21, 2012 saw over 12,000 participants march through the city of Brisbane. With a new [[music festival]] format added to the event, Brisbane Zombie Walk raised $55,000 for the Brain Foundation of Australia, making them the most successful zombie charity event in the world. In 2011, the Brisbane Zombie Walk made over $25,000 for the Brain Foundation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-21/thousands-of-zombies-take-to-brisbane-streets/4325732 |title=Thousands of Zombies Take to Brisbane Streets |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
==Pub crawl variant== [[File:Zombie Crawl Copenhagen 2011 Kim Bach Flickr.ogv|thumb|Copenhagen Zombie Crawl 2011 – held on June 1 (the night before [[Ascension Day]])]] Some zombie walks incorporate [[pub crawl]]ing, during which participants visit multiple bars over the course of the walk. The first large-scale zombie pub crawl was held in [[Minneapolis]] on October 15, 2005. The crawl consisted of roughly 150 participants in zombie costumes moving from bar to bar in the city's [[Northeast, Minneapolis|Northeast]] district. The Minneapolis "Zombie Pub Crawl" has since become an annual event and attendance has grown exponentially; each year it takes place in a different area of the city.<ref>Horgen, Tom.[http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/dining/31116719.html?elr=KArksD:aDyaEP:kD:aUt:aDyaEP:kD:aUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aULPQL7PQLanchO7DiU Nightlife: 'Dead' ahead] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101210913/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/dining/31116719.html?elr=KArksD%3AaDyaEP%3AkD%3AaUt%3AaDyaEP%3AkD%3AaUiD3aPc%3A_Yyc%3AaULPQL7PQLanchO7DiU |date=November 1, 2014 }} ''[[Star Tribune]]''. October 16, 2008.</ref>
Similar large-scale zombie-themed pub crawls have developed in [[New Orleans]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nolazombies.blogspot.com/ |title=NOLA Zombie Pub Crawl |publisher=Nolazombies.blogspot.com |date=May 28, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> [[Providence, Rhode Island]], [[Reno]], [[Houston]], [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin|Eau Claire]], Chicago,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagozombiepubcrawl.com/ |title=Chicago Zombie Pub Crawl |publisher=Chicago Zombie Pub Crawl |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> and [[Philadelphia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phillyzombiecrawl.com/ |title=Home to the Philly Zombie Crawl and Philly Zombie Prom! |publisher=PhillyZombieCrawl.com |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> Philadelphia's zombie pub crawl is held on [[Easter]] Sunday in celebration of [[Jesus]], "the world's most famous zombie". Zombie pub crawls are now a regular occurrence in cities all over the world. The New York City Zombie Crawl has involved attendees walk all over Manhattan and drink at different pubs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sakmann|first=Doug|title=NYC Zombie Crawl|url=http://nyczombiecrawl.com/news/|publisher=Doug Sakmann}}</ref> In 2007, the Viking Hats group organized a [[Halloween]] zombie walk in [[London]] that ended at the Tate London.<ref>{{cite web |title=Capcom Zombies Invade London |url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2009/11/capcom-zombies-invade-london/ |publisher=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=June 29, 2012 |first=Mike |last=Fahey |date=November 3, 2009}}</ref> London's Zombie Pub Crawl has become an annual Halloween weekend event.<ref>{{cite web |title=What Pub Crawl Means? |url=http://www.nutspubcrawl.co.uk/nutspubcrawllondon/ |publisher=Nuts Pub Crawl |accessdate=June 29, 2012 |date=March 22, 2012}}</ref>
In 2007, zombies used bicycles to travel around town in the initial Ride of the Living Dead event in [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]]. An offshoot of the non-zombie summer Handlebars and Bars bicycle pub crawl, this event began with about 40 riders in its debut, and has since grown exponentially. In 2014, the event attracted over 400 zombie bicyclists and featured indie-rock bands from the Milwaukee-Chicago corridor as entertainment throughout the day.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/pages/Handlebars-and-BarsRide-of-the-Living-Dead Handlebars and BarsRide of the Living Dead | Facebook]{{dead link|date=December 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref>
==Incidents== In 2006, a young woman in [[Bloomington, Indiana]] reported to police that a group of "zombies" attacked her car by covering the vehicle in "purple goo"; the zombies in question turned out to be participants in a small, local zombie walk, and several arrests were made.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldtimesonline.com/stories/2006/11/01/news.1101-HT-A3_LJB09259.sto |title=Woman reports zombie attack |work=[[The Herald-Times]] |accessdate=January 28, 2010}}</ref> At the 2006 Vancouver Zombie Walk, an incident occurred in which two impatient drivers attempted to drive their cars through a crowd of zombies headed down Robson Street: this resulted in some severe injuries among the zombies, but no damage to the vehicles. Another incident involved a pair of zombies using a brick to shatter the window of a man's car; both zombies were arrested.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldengod.net/2006/09/07/vancouver-zombiewalk-2006-cbc-footage/ |title=Vancouver Zombie Walk 2006 CBC TV Coverage |publisher=Goldengod.net |date=September 7, 2006 |accessdate=January 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722065855/http://www.goldengod.net/2006/09/07/vancouver-zombiewalk-2006-cbc-footage/ |archivedate=July 22, 2009 }}</ref>
In 2010, the annual Zombie Shuffle in [[Melbourne]] saw the largest attendance in its five-year history, but some locals complained of the mess that the zombie "gore" left behind, as well as the walk's disruption of a play for [[Preschool education|preschoolers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/opinion/ghoul-chant-is-gory-gory-hallelujah/story-e6frfhqf-1225862262752 |title=Ghoul chant is gory, gory hallelujah |work=[[Herald Sun]] |date=May 5, 2010 |accessdate=June 14, 2010}}</ref> In 2011 and 2012, participants in the [[Minneapolis]] Zombie Pub Crawl broke store windows and caused other damage to the area in which the event was held. Many residents see the event as disruptive to the life of the neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2013/10/11/zombie-crawl-organizers-add-security-to-fight-nimby-vibe|title=Zombie Pub Crawl adds security as some Cedar-Riverside businesses moan|first=Jon|last=Collins|date=October 10, 2011|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> In 2012, a Russian zombie walk in support of [[Pussy Riot]] in [[Omsk]], [[Siberia]] was banned by the local government.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.ria.ru/society/20120816/175253222.html |title=Siberia's Omsk Bans Zombie Parade in Support of Pussy Riot |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/politics/zombie-parade-church-ban-820/ |title='Zombie Parade' banned in Siberia |publisher=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]}}</ref>
In October 2015, a shooting occurred at the ZombiCon in [[Fort Myers, Florida]]. <ref name="Mullen">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/18/us/zombicon-shooting-fort-myers-florida/index.html|title=Deadly shooting sparks panic at ZombiCon event in Fort Myers, Florida|last=Mullen|first=Jethro|author2=Joe Sutton|date=October 18, 2015|publisher=CNN|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref> 1 person was killed and 5 others were wounded. Lawsuits led to cancellation of the event the next year. <ref name="Braun">{{cite web|url=http://www.news-press.com/story/news/2016/09/25/no-zombicon-fort-myers-2016-public-relations-firm-confirms/91091336/|title=Zombicon canceled for 2016 as lawsuits swirl|last=Braun|first=Michelle|date=September 25, 2016|publisher=News-Press|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref>
